CHAPTER XCIV.

OF POLISHING GEMS.

CRYSTAL, which is water hardened into ice, and the ice of great age is hardened into stone, is trimmed and polished in this manner. Take the composition which is called tenax, of which mention is made above, and applying it to the fire until it liquefy, you will fasten the crystal to a long. wood, which must be similar to it in thickness. When this has be- come cold, you will rub it with both hands upon a hard sand- stone, water being added, until it takes the form which γοα wish to give it, then upon another stone of the same kind, which must be finer and smoother, until it be made quite smootli. And taking a flat leaden tablet, place moistened tile upon it, which you will rub with saliva upon a hard hone, and you polish this crystal upon it until it takes a lustrc. But at last, place the rubbing of tile, made moist with saliva, upon a goat's skin, neither blackened nor oiled, but stretched upon wood and fixed below with nails, and rub carefully upon it, until it becomes quite bright.
